definitions.definition: used with uncountable nouns or plural countable nouns to mean ‘an amount of’ or ‘a number of’, when the amount or number is not given

examples.text: There's some milk in the fridge.

definitions.definition: used to refer to certain members of a group or certain types of a thing, but not all of them

examples.text: Some people find this more difficult than others.
Some people never seem to put on weight while others are always on a diet.
I like some modern music *(= but not all of it)*.

definitions.definition: a large number or amount of something

examples.text: It was with some surprise that I heard the news.
We've known each other for some years now.
We're going to be working together for **some time** *(= a long time)*.

definitions.definition: a small amount or number of something

examples.text: There is some hope that things will improve.

definitions.definition: used with singular nouns to refer to a person, place, thing or time that is not known or not identified

examples.text: She won a competition in **some** newspaper **or other**.
I'll see you again some time, I'm sure.

definitions.definition: used to express a positive or negative opinion about somebody/something

examples.text: Some expert you are! You know even less than me.

wordOrigin: Old English sum, of Germanic origin, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek hamōs ‘somehow’ and Sanskrit sama ‘any, every’.
